entry.title: LeetCode 19. Remove Nth Node From End of List
entry.content:
Problem

Give a linked list, remove the $n^{th}$ node from the end of list and return its head.

Example

Given linked list: 1->2->3->4->5, and n = 2
After removing the second node from the end, the linked list becomes 1->2->3->5.

Note

Given n will always be valid.
Try do this in one pass.

Answer

entry.title: LeetCode 751. IP to CIDR
entry.content:
Problem

Given a start IP address ip and a number of ips we need to cover n, return a representation of the range as a list (of smallest possible length) of CIDR blocks.

A CIDR block is a string consisting of an IP, followed by a slash, and then prefix length. For example: â€œ123.45.67.89/20â€. That prefix length â€œ20â€ represents the number of common prefix bits in the specified range.

Example 1

Input: ip = â€œ255.0.0.7â€, n = 10
Output: [â€œ255.0.0.7/32â€, â€œ255,0.0.8/29â€, â€œ255.0.0.16/32â€]
Explanation:
The initial ip address, when convered to binary, look like this (spaces added for clarity):
255.0.0.7 -> 1111111 00000000 00000000 00000111
The address â€œ255.0.0.7/32â€ specifies all address with a common prefix of 32 bits to the given address,
ie. just this one address.

The address â€œ255.0.0.8/29â€ specifies all address with a common prefix of 29 bits to the given address:
255.0.0.8 -> 11111111 00000000 0000000 00001000
Address with common prefix of 29 bits are:
11111111 00000000 00000000 00001000
11111111 00000000 00000000 00001001
11111111 00000000 00000000 00001010
11111111 00000000 00000000 00001011
11111111 00000000 00000000 00001100
11111111 00000000 00000000 00001101
11111111 00000000 00000000 00001110
11111111 00000000 00000000 00001111

The address â€œ255.0.0.16/32â€ specifies all address with a common prefix of 32 bits to the given address,
ie. just 11111111 00000000 00000000 00010000

In total, the answer specifies the range of 10 ips starting with the address 255.0.0.7 .

There were other representations, such as:
[â€œ255.0.0.7/32â€, â€œâ€255.0.0.8/30â€, â€œ255.0.0.12/30â€, â€œ255.0.0.16/32â€],
but our answer was the shortest possible.

Also note that a representation beginning with say, â€œ255.0.0.7/30â€ would be incorrect,
because it includes address like 255.0.0.4 = 11111111 00000000 00000000 00000100
that are outside the specified range.

Note

  1. ip will be a valid IPv4 address.
  2. Every implied address ip + x (for x < n) will be a valid IPv4 address.
  3. n will be an integer in the range [1, 1000].

Answer

è¿™ä¸ªé—®é¢˜æ˜¯åœ¨ç»™å®šçš„èµ·å§‹IPåœ°å€ï¼Œæ±‚æœ€å°‘çš„CIDRæ­£å¥½è¦†ç›–nä¸ªIPåœ°å€ã€‚æ‰€æ±‚çš„åœ°å€è¦æ±‚æ˜¯è¿ç»­çš„ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”è¦åœ¨èµ·å§‹IPçš„åé¢ã€‚

å…ˆè¯´æ˜ä¸€ä¸‹255.255.0.8/29ä¸­29çš„å«ä¹‰ï¼š
ä¸€ä¸ªIPv4çš„åœ°å€æ€»å…±æœ‰32ä½ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è¡¨ç¤º29è¡¨ç¤ºçš„æ˜¯IPçš„å‰29ä¸ºæ˜¯å›ºå®šçš„ï¼Œåä¸‰ä½å¯ä»¥æ”¹å˜ï¼Œå› æ­¤å¯ä»¥è¦†ç›–$2^3$(8)ä¸ªIPã€‚é‚£ä¹ˆè¦ä½¿CIDRå°½é‡çš„å°‘ï¼Œå°±è®©å›ºå®šçš„IPçš„ä½æ•°å°½é‡å°‘ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶è¦ä¿è¯IPæ˜¯è¿ç»­çš„ã€‚

æ¯”å¦‚æˆ‘ä»¬ä»¥255.0.0.7å¼€å§‹ï¼Œè¦†ç›–30ä¸ªåœ°å€ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå°±æœ‰ï¼š

255.0.0.7/32
åªæœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªIPåœ°å€ å‰©ä½™30 - 1 = 29

æ¥ä¸‹æ¥çš„IPåœ°å€æ˜¯ 255.0.0.8ï¼Œæœ€å8ä½æ˜¯: 00001000ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰3ä½å¯ä»¥æ›´æ”¹
åˆ™æœ‰255.0.0.8/29 å¯ä»¥è¦†ç›–8ä¸ªIPï¼Œå‰©ä½™29 - 8 = 21

8ä¸ªåœ°å€åçš„IPæ˜¯255.0.0.16ï¼Œæœ€å8ä½æ˜¯: 00010000ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰4ä½å¯ä»¥æ›´æ”¹
åˆ™æœ‰255.0.0.16/28 å¯ä»¥è¦†ç›–16ä¸ªIPï¼Œå‰©ä½™21 - 16 = 5

æ¥ä¸‹æ¥çš„IPåœ°å€æ˜¯255.0.0.32ï¼Œæœ€å8ä½æ˜¯ï¼š 00100000ï¼Œè¿˜æœ‰5ä½å¯ä»¥æ›´æ”¹ï¼Œè€Œå‰©ä½™çš„è¦è¦†ç›–çš„IPåªæœ‰5ä¸ªï¼Œå› æ­¤è¦å°äº5ï¼Œå¦åˆ™è¦†ç›–çš„IPèŒƒå›´å°±ä¼šè¶…è¿‡ç»™å®šçš„ä¸ªæ•°ï¼Œå› æ­¤æ˜¯4ä¸ªï¼Œå³å¯¹æœ€åä¸¤ä½è¿›è¡Œæ›´æ”¹
åˆ™æœ‰255.0.0.32/30 å¯ä»¥è¦†ç›–4ä¸ªIPï¼Œå‰©ä½™5 - 4 = 1

é‚£ä¹ˆæœ€åä¸€ä¸ªè¦è¦†ç›–çš„å°±æ˜¯255.0.0.36/32ï¼Œå‰©ä½™0ä¸ªè¦è¦†ç›–
